paragraph: The Tale Of Benjamin Bunny Beatrix Potter
FOR THE CHILDREN OF SAWREY
tokens: children

paragraph: FROM     OLD MR. BUNNY
tokens: old

paragraph: BOOK 1.
One morning a little rabbit sat on a bank.
tokens: morning little rabbit sit bank

paragraph: He pricked his ears and listened to the trit-trot, trit-trot of a pony.
tokens: prick ear listen trit trot trit trot pony

paragraph: A gig was coming along the road; it was driven by Mr. McGregor, and beside him sat Mrs. McGregor in her best bonnet.
tokens: gig come road drive sit good bonnet

paragraph: As soon as they had passed, little Benjamin Bunny slid down into the road, and set off--with a hop, skip, and a jump--to call upon his relations, who lived in the wood at the back of Mr. McGregor's garden.
tokens: pass little slide road set hop skip jump call relation live wood back garden

paragraph: That wood was full of rabbit holes; and in the neatest, sandiest hole of all lived Benjamin's aunt and his cousins--Flopsy, Mopsy, Cotton-tail, and Peter.
tokens: wood full rabbit hole neatest sandiest hole live aunt cousin tail

paragraph: Old Mrs. Rabbit was a widow; she earned her living by knitting rabbit-wool mittens and muffatees (I once bought a pair at a bazaar). She also sold herbs, and rosemary tea, and rabbit-tobacco (which is what we call lavender).
tokens: old widow earn living knitting rabbit wool mitten muffatee buy pair bazaar sell herb rosemary tea rabbit tobacco call lavender

paragraph: Little Benjamin did not very much want to see his Aunt.
tokens: little want see aunt

paragraph: He came round the back of the fir-tree, and nearly tumbled upon the top of his Cousin Peter.
tokens: come back fir tree tumble top cousin

paragraph: Peter was sitting by himself. He looked poorly, and was dressed in a red cotton pocket-handkerchief.
tokens: sit look dress red cotton pocket handkerchief

paragraph: "Peter," said little Benjamin, in a whisper, "who has got your clothes?"
tokens: say little whisper get clothes

paragraph: Peter replied, "The scarecrow in Mr. McGregor's garden," and described how he had been chased about the garden, and had dropped his shoes and coat.
tokens: reply scarecrow garden describe chase garden drop shoe coat

paragraph: Little Benjamin sat down beside his cousin and assured him that Mr. McGregor had gone out in a gig, and Mrs. McGregor also; and certainly for the day, because she was wearing her best bonnet.
tokens: little sit cousin assure go gig day wear good bonnet

paragraph: Peter said he hoped that it would rain.
tokens: say hope rain

paragraph: At this point old Mrs. Rabbit's voice was heard inside the rabbit hole, calling: "Cotton-tail! Cotton-tail! fetch some more camomile!"
tokens: point old voice hear rabbit hole call cotton tail cotton tail fetch more camomile

paragraph: Peter said he thought he might feel better if he went for a walk.
tokens: say think feel good go walk

paragraph: They went away hand in hand, and got upon the flat top of the wall at the bottom of the wood. From here they looked down into Mr. McGregor's garden. Peter's coat and shoes were plainly to be seen upon the scarecrow, topped with an old tam-o'-shanter of Mr. McGregor's.
tokens: go hand hand get flat top wall bottom wood look garden coat shoe see scarecrow top old tam o' shanter

paragraph: Little Benjamin said: "It spoils people's clothes to squeeze under a gate; the proper way to get in is to climb down a pear-tree."
tokens: little say spoil person clothes squeeze gate proper way get climb pear tree

paragraph: Peter fell down head first; but it was of no consequence, as the bed below was newly raked and quite soft.
tokens: fall head consequence bed rake soft

paragraph: It had been sown with lettuces.
tokens: sow lettuce

paragraph: They left a great many odd little footmarks all over the bed, especially little Benjamin, who was wearing clogs.
tokens: leave great many odd little footmark bed little wear clog

paragraph: Little Benjamin said that the first thing to be done was to get back Peter's clothes, in order that they might be able to use the pocket-handkerchief.
tokens: little say first thing do get clothes order able use pocket handkerchief

paragraph: They took them off the scarecrow. There had been rain during the night; there was water in the shoes, and the coat was somewhat shrunk.
tokens: take scarecrow be rain night be water shoe coat shrink

paragraph: Benjamin tried on the tam-o'-shanter, but it was too big for him.
tokens: try tam o' shanter big

paragraph: Then he suggested that they should fill the pocket-handkerchief with onions, as a little present for his Aunt.
tokens: suggest fill pocket handkerchief onion little present aunt

paragraph: Peter did not seem to be enjoying himself; he kept hearing noises.
tokens: seem enjoy keep hear noise

paragraph: Benjamin, on the contrary, was perfectly at home, and ate a lettuce leaf. He said that he was in the habit of coming to the garden with his father to get lettuces for their Sunday dinner.
tokens: contrary home eat lettuce leaf say habit come garden father get lettuce dinner

paragraph: (The name of little Benjamin's papa was old Mr. Benjamin Bunny.)
tokens: name little papa old

paragraph: The lettuces certainly were very fine.
tokens: lettuce fine

paragraph: Peter did not eat anything; he said he should like to go home. Presently he dropped half the onions.
tokens: eat say like go drop onion

paragraph: Little Benjamin said that it was not possible to get back up the pear-tree with a load of vegetables. He led the way boldly towards the other end of the garden. They went along a little walk on planks, under a sunny, red brick wall.
tokens: little say possible get pear tree load vegetable lead way other end garden go little walk plank sunny red brick wall

paragraph: The mice sat on their doorsteps cracking cherry-stones; they winked at Peter Rabbit and little Benjamin Bunny.
tokens: mouse sit doorstep crack cherry stone wink little

paragraph: Presently Peter let the pocket-handkerchief go again.
tokens: let pocket handkerchief go

paragraph: They got amongst flower-pots, and frames, and tubs. Peter heard noises worse than ever; his eyes were as big as lolly-pops!
tokens: get flower pot frame tub hear noise bad eye big lolly pop

paragraph: He was a step or two in front of his cousin when he suddenly stopped.
tokens: step front cousin stop

paragraph: This is what those little rabbits saw round that corner!
tokens: little rabbit see corner

paragraph: Little Benjamin took one look, and then, in half a minute less than no time, he hid himself and Peter and the onions underneath a large basket....
tokens: little take look minute less time hide onion large basket

paragraph: The cat got up and stretched herself, and came and sniffed at the basket.
tokens: cat get stretch come sniff basket

paragraph: Perhaps she liked the smell of onions!
tokens: like smell onion

paragraph: Anyway, she sat down upon the top of the basket.
tokens: sit top basket

paragraph: She sat there for _five hours_.
tokens: sit hours_

paragraph: I cannot draw you a picture of Peter and Benjamin underneath the basket, because it was quite dark, and because the smell of onions was fearful; it made Peter Rabbit and little Benjamin cry.
tokens: draw picture basket dark smell onion fearful make little cry

paragraph: The sun got round behind the wood, and it was quite late in the afternoon; but still the cat sat upon the basket.
tokens: sun get wood late afternoon cat sit basket

paragraph: At length there was a pitter-patter, pitter-patter, and some bits of mortar fell from the wall above.
tokens: length be pitter patter pitter patter bit mortar fall wall

paragraph: The cat looked up and saw old Mr. Benjamin Bunny prancing along the top of the wall of the upper terrace.
tokens: cat look see old prance top wall upper terrace

paragraph: He was smoking a pipe of rabbit-tobacco, and had a little switch in his hand.
tokens: smoke pipe rabbit tobacco have little switch hand

paragraph: He was looking for his son.
tokens: look son

paragraph: Old Mr. Bunny had no opinion whatever of cats.
tokens: old have opinion cat

paragraph: He took a tremendous jump off the top of the wall on to the top of the cat, and cuffed it off the basket, and kicked it into the greenhouse, scratching off a handful of fur.
tokens: take tremendous jump top wall top cat cuff basket kick greenhouse scratch handful fur

paragraph: The cat was too much surprised to scratch back.
tokens: cat surprised scratch

paragraph: When old Mr. Bunny had driven the cat into the greenhouse, he locked the door.
tokens: old drive cat greenhouse lock door

paragraph: Then he came back to the basket and took out his son Benjamin by the ears, and whipped him with the little switch.
tokens: come basket take son ear whip little switch

paragraph: Then he took out his nephew Peter.
tokens: take nephew

paragraph: Then he took out the handkerchief of onions, and marched out of the garden.
tokens: take handkerchief onion march garden

paragraph: When Mr. McGregor returned about half an hour later he observed several things which perplexed him.
tokens: return hour observe several thing perplex

paragraph: It looked as though some person had been walking all over the garden in a pair of clogs--only the footmarks were too ridiculously little!
tokens: look person walk garden pair clog footmark little

paragraph: Also he could not understand how the cat could have managed to shut herself up _inside_ the greenhouse, locking the door upon the _outside_.
tokens: understand cat manage shut greenhouse lock door _outside_

paragraph: When Peter got home his mother forgave him, because she was so glad to see that he had found his shoes and coat. Cotton-tail and Peter folded up the pocket-handkerchief, and old Mrs. Rabbit strung up the onions and hung them from the kitchen ceiling, with the bunches of herbs and the rabbit-tobacco.
tokens: get mother forgive glad see find shoe coat cotton tail fold pocket handkerchief old string onion hang kitchen ceiling bunch herb rabbit tobacco

paragraph: THE END
tokens: end
